CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle nodes tested.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every triangle node tested. If this value is high then the ray tracing unit spent a lot of time testing for intersection with triangles, and can be caused by high triangle counts, acceleration structure inefficiency, and ray divergence across a warp.
Nodes have a variable duration that depends on the number of triangles they contain, and the number of active rays in each warp.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of acceleration structure bounding boxes tested.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every acceleration structure bounding box node tested. If this value is high then the ray tracing unit spent a lot of time traversing the acceleration structure. High node counts, acceleration structure inefficiency, and ray divergence across a warp can all cause the counter value to be high.
Nodes have a variable duration that depends on the number of bounding boxes they contain, and the number of active rays in each warp.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing triangle nodes with 1-4 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle nodes with 1 to 4 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every triangle node tested when there are between 1 and 4 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing triangle nodes with 5-8 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle nodes with 5 to 8 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every triangle node tested when there are between 5 and 8 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing triangle nodes with 9-12 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle nodes with 9 to 12 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every triangle node tested when there are between 9 and 12 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing triangle nodes with 13-16 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle nodes with 13 to 16 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every triangle node tested when there are between 13 and 16 active rays in the warp.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing box nodes with 1-4 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of acceleration structure box nodes with 1 to 4 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every acceleration structure box node tested when there are between 1 and 4 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing box nodes with 5-8 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of acceleration structure box nodes with 5 to 8 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every acceleration structure box node tested when there are between 5 and 8 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing box nodes with 9-12 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of acceleration structure box nodes with 9 to 12 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every acceleration structure box node tested when there are between 9 and 12 active rays in the warp. A high percentage of tests with low warp occupancy can indicate an issue with ray coherency. Try to group rays with similar origin, direction, and range together.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing box nodes with 13-16 rays
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of acceleration structure box nodes with 13 to 16 active rays in the warp.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This count increments for every acceleration structure box node tested when there are between 13 and 16 active rays in the warp.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of opaque triangle hits.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter increments for every ray intersection with an opaque triangle.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of non-opaque triangle hits.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every ray intersection with a non-opaque triangle.
Non-opaque triangles are more expensive to process than opaque triangles, so Arm recommends using opaque triangles in acceleration structures.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of rays that terminate on their first hit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every ray that terminates on its first triangle hit. Rays that terminate on first hit are more efficient to process, as they do not need to keep testing to find the closest hit.
First-hit tests are well suited to techniques that determine occlusion, such as shadow mapping. In these use cases you don't need to know which object is hit, just that an object was hit between the ray source and destination.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangle intersection tests that do not intersect.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every ray-triangle intersection test that does not intersect the triangle.
Most triangles that a ray misses are expected to be culled by box tests during acceleration structure traversal, so if rays are triggering a high number of triangle intersection tests, try improving the acceleration structure quality.
A high number for this counter might also indicate a programming error, such as using opaque triangles and requesting that opaque hits be culled.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of rays started.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter increments for every ray that is started and tested against the root node in the acceleration structure.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing box tester issue cycles
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of active issue cycles for the ray tracing box test unit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every clock cycle the ray tracing unit issues a box intersection operation. If this counter is a high percentage of shader core active, then shader performance might be limited by acceleration structure traversal.
The main workload for ray tracing is traversing the acceleration structure so this counter is expected to be high. If the counter is not high, and a significant number of rays are being used, it indicates that a bottleneck exists elsewhere.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of boxes issued to the ray tracing unit box test data path.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every bounding box tested by the ray tracing unit box intersection operation.
The main workload for ray tracing is traversing the acceleration structure so this counter is expected to be high. If the counter is not high, and a significant number of rays are being used, it indicates that a bottleneck exists elsewhere.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of boxes from the TLAS issued to the ray tracing unit box test data path.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every top level acceleration structure bounding box tested by the ray tracing unit box intersection operation.
The main workload for ray tracing is traversing the acceleration structure so this counter is expected to be high. If the counter is not high, and a significant number of rays are being used, it indicates that a bottleneck exists elsewhere.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of BLAS instances processed by the ray tracing unit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of BLAS instances processed by the ray tracing unit. Some instances might be culled without traversing the BLAS itself

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of BLAS instances culled by by the ray tracing unit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of BLAS instances culled by the ray tracing unit due to no intersection.

CounterInfo.HumanName: Ray tracing triangle tester issue cycles
CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of active issue cycles for the ray tracing triangle test unit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every clock cycle the ray tracing unit issues a triangle intersection test. If this counter is a high percentage of shader core active, then shader performance might be limited by triangle testing.
A good acceleration structure culls most triangles using box tests higher up the tree, so that rays do not need to be tested against them. If this counter is high it might indicate an issue with either geometry complexity or acceleration structure efficiency.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of primitives culled by the ray tracing unit testers.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter increments for every triangle and bounding box culled by the ray tracing unit test units.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of triangles issued to the ray tracing unit triangle test data path.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This counter increments for every triangle tested by the ray tracing unit triangle intersection operation.
A good acceleration structure culls most triangles using box tests higher up the tree, so that rays do not need to be tested against them. If this counter is high it might indicate an issue with either geometry complexity or acceleration structure efficiency.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The total number of ray tracing unit active cycles.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the total number of cycles when the ray tracing unit is active with at least one operation.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of cycles the ray tracing unit was issuing work.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This expression defines the total number of cycles when the ray tracing unit was issuing work to a functional unit.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The percentage utilization of the ray tracing unit.
CounterInfo.LongDescription:
This expression defines the percentage utilization of the ray tracing unit.
The most effective technique for reducing ray tracing load is reducing the amount of geometry in the acceleration structure, and ensuring that rays issued in each warp are spatially coherent.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of hits in the ray tracing unit cache.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of triangle and box data lookups that hit in the ray tracing unit cache.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of misses in the ray tracing unit cache.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of triangle and box data lookups that miss in the ray tracing unit cache.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of ray tracing messages starting new rays.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of ray tracing messages starting new rays.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of ray tracing messages resuming existing rays.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of ray tracing messages resuming tracing of existing rays.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of rays that are resumed after an initial hit or intersection shader.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of rays that are resumed after an initial hit or intersection shader.

CounterInfo.ShortDescription: The number of rays that are using a deep traversal stack.
CounterInfo.LongDescription: This counter defines the number of rays that use a deep traversal stack.
